Posts.Content: lorieg wrote: Hi ladies.  Well, I was finally able to have my bilateral MRM and am about to start rads.  All finally seems to be going well.  I was looking at my PET scan results from prior to surgery and they note a "ground glass opacity" in my right upper lobe that has not changed in appearance since my CT in 8/09 at diagnosis (prior to any chemo/treatment).  Of course my CT report from 8/09 does not metion this nodule.  That CT was read by my local hospital.  The new PET was read by MDA.  The PET result recommended watching the nodule, but read out as no evidence of malignancy.  I wasn't too concerned until I read about ground glass nodules and now I am concerned as they have a high risk of malignancy.  My oncologist does not seem at all concerned, but I am now freaking ou a bit.  I have no ther medical problems. Anyone with any experience with ground glass nodules prior to treatment/rads? Thanks! Posts.Content: lorieg wrote: Hi everyone, I am going to try and make this as short as possible! I was diagnosed 8/09 with stage IV IBC at the age of 32.....fast forward to 1/2012.....diagnosed with lung, bone, brain, ovarian mets after previously having just metastatic pleural effusions and skin mets.  I was put on TCH after WBR in January of this year.  I had 6 cycles of TCH with a "complete chemo response."  In May, other than the small pleural effusions my PET scan was normal.  Yea!!  I was taken off Taxotere (despite my protests) but left on Carbo and Herceptin.  As always happens every time a chemo is stopped, I am pretty positive I am having progression.  I have worsening shortness of breath, a new yet different very tight cough, and skin mets appear to be returning.  I have only been off Taxotere for about two months.  Question.....Has anyone had success going back on a chemo (like Taxotere in this case) that worked great but after stopping it there was a short time to progression?  Pretty sure they won't put me back on the Taxotere but wondering what you all have experienced.  I am running out of chemo options.  My mets are ER/PR neg, btw. I see my onc this week for C/H.  I am leaving after chemo for a long-planned trip for 2.5 weeks with my husband and two young kids.  I am going regardless as I need to make these memories, and well, you know.... Thoughts?  Thank you so much, and sorry this was so long! Lori Lori, age 33, dx IBC Stage IV 8/09, Grade 3, ER+/PR-/Her2+, married with a 4 year old son and a 1 year old daughter Dx 8/21/2009, IBC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/25 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2009 10:13PM - edited Dec 26, 2009 11:22PM by lorieg Notinvincible, Hi and so sorry you had to join this club.  The first few days-week are the worst part about all of this nightmare.  The fear of the unknown is horrible.  You will get through it.  It does get easier as time passes.  I am also in the process of doing neoadjuvant chemo and have not had surgery yet.  I was diagnosed in August of this year at the age of 32.  I have a 4 year old son and a now 11 month old daughter.   I wish I could tell you not to worry about your aching knees and the fear of mets but nothing anyone says will take that worry away from you until you see clean scans!  I have Inflammatory Breast Cancer, which is extremely aggressive.  My entire breast is involved.  I went misdiagnosed for months and was absolutely sure the cancer would be everywhere at diagnosis...it was not found in any major organs.  I have been having back and shoulder pain and very much expected to have mets on my recent PET scan, but it too was clean for mets.  Not all pain is mets.... I am sending prayers and positive thoughts your way.  Big hugs!    Lori

Posts.Content: lorieg wrote: Hi everyone!  I feel I have no right to come here asking for help since I have been MIA for the last few months.  I needed a little break as I was spending too much time online.  I would really appreciate your advice as many of you have been at this game longer than me.  Thanks in advance. So, after a short month or so break from Ixempra (while still on Herceptin and Tykerb) my once stable pleural effusions came roaring back. I had been on Ixempra with stability for about 6 months when it was recommended I take a break. Prior to this I maintained stability with no progression on Xeloda and Tykerb for over a year. The Xeloda was stopped while I was NED and within two months the effusions became apparent. Basically when I am on chemo I seem to stay stable, but as soon as I go off things flare back up again. Fine, I can deal with chemo for the rest of my life. HERE IS MY QUESTION........anyone with thoughts/experiences/etc, please chime in. Do I go back on one of the chemos that seemed to keep me stable even though within 1-2 months of stopping them I get worse OR do I try a new chemo? I have never had visible progression while on chemo. My MDA onc said in the past I failed the chemo because I recurred within 8 weeks of stopping it. My local onc thinks go back to what seemed to get and keep me stable. Thoughts? THANK YOU!!!! Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2010 08:00PM lorieg wrote: Hi ladies.  I had my bilateral modified radical mastectomy yesterday.  It went really well.  I was very calm and almost excited to just get it done.  After 8 months of chemo I was starting to think I would never get to surgery, but the chemo finally worked!  I had somewhat of a fear of general anesthesia but everything was great.  My pain is very tolerable.  I was out of surgery at 2:30 pm yesterday, had my last IV pain med at 5:30pm yesterday and have had a total of 4 percocets in the last 24 hours.  I think that is pretty darn good!  I have two drains on each side which are rather annoying but not a big deal.  I was walking the halls last night and discharged from the hospital this morning. Anyway, this is the part of the process I was dreading the most and so far it has been smooth sailing.  My surgeon was extremely pleased with what she saw in surgery, but the 3-4 day wait for the path report is going to be tough. Just wanted  to offer encouragement to others as I know I was a bit nervous about this process.  Because I have IBC I can not even consider reconstruction for a few years, but the chest is not nearly as ugly as I was picturing it.  I told my BS that if I was alive in a few years then I would consider seein  a plastic surgeon! Good luck to everyone next week and let me know if you have any questions!  Hugs, Lori

Posts.Content: lorieg wrote: Hi all, So, I had my 6th thoracentesis today. Give me some lidocaine and a french catheter, and I think I can tap myself at home now :-)   I asked the very nice radiologist what my lungs looked like on yesterday's scans. He took me to his office and reviewed the scans in detail as I was going to wait to see my oncologist on friday for chemo and results. We know I have bilateral metastatic pleural effusions that continue to form, but I also have ill-defined changes in my lungs that they have presumed, since the development of the pleural mets, are evidence of lymphangitic spread. In addition, my CT six weeks ago showed enlarged hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes. My CT chest/abd/pelvis from yesterday showed no lymphadenopathy in the chest (which is an improvement). The radiologist also said that the changes he sees in the lung parenchyma look very much like pneumonitis and fibrosis and NOT like lymphangitic mets (which, if true is good). Also the rest of my organs and bones appear normal. So, basically we are mostly just dealing with these stubborn pleural effusions that continue to re-form and are very large. Based on this I think I would call things stable-mildly improved. I see my onc on Friday and will see what he has to say. Continue Ixempra/Herceptin? Consider something else? I would guess continue with the course of treatment based on the scans. One other thing.....I have nodules on my chest that, although have not been biopsied are most definitely skin mets. These are pretty much stable, not better not worse. Thoughts?? xoxoxo, Lori Lori, age 33, dx IBC Stage IV 8/09, Grade 3, ER+/PR-/Her2+, married with a 4 year old son and a 1 year old daughter Dx 8/21/2009, IBC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/25 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: lorieg wrote: My 4 year old son knows I have cancer and that I am being treated by doctors.  He knows what is appropriate to know at 4 years of age.  I am careful not to discuss my fears of dying and leaving my young children when he is around.  In fact, I rarely talk about it at all anymore.  The first few months after diagnosis I would have to hold back to tears every time he said "when i grow up..." Yesterday, out of no where...... Son- "Mommy, are you going to die before me?" Me- "Well, yes, sweetie, I am older than you so I think so."  (something like this, forget my exact words) Son- "I don't want you to die before me, Mommy." Me- "Why, baby?" Son- "Because I don't want to be alone." Ouch.  Broke my heart.  I am not sure if this is something he has picked up on or random thoughts by a 4 year old.  I went on to explain that he will never be alone, has so many people who love him and care for him, including my husband/his daddy.  Eight months ago I would have left the room and burst out into tears at this conversation.  Just wanted to share with people who understand. Thanks. Posts.Content: lorieg wrote: I hope it is ok that I post here.  I am pretty positive I am stage IV (see signature) although still holding onto a little hope that I may have bilateral breast cancer as opposed to mets.  My oncologist and my second opinion oncologist disagree slightly on this matter but at least agreed on treatment. Anyway, I realize that scans would help me with this answer and this is a not very scientific poll, but I was wondering if those of you with bone mets can decribe what your symptoms were like, if you had any??  I have been having very odd back pain in my thoracic spine in a few spots.  I am 33 and have never had back pain other than a few minor sprains here and there and this definitely does not feel like a muscle issue.  The pain does not keep me up or really bother me at night, and it is not even significant enough to bother taking tylenol/ibuprofen, but it does persist when the other bone pain from the chemo has subsided.  I have had 4 rounds of A/C and am through two rounds of Taxol/Herceptin.  It started at least a month ago but was so intermittent I didn't think much of it at first.  I do have a 10 month old daughter  (and 4 year old son) so carrying them around may be part of this issue (I hope!).  I did discuss this with my onc who said we could get an MRI but he thought it was unlikely that I have bone mets since my bone scan was clean prior to treatment.  He also said that at this point we would still just finish the taxol/herceptin and so treatment now would not change although obviously it would change future treatment.  I decided to hold on the MRI and live in my little dream world where I do not have major organ mets yet, but this pain is nagging and annoying *mentally*. Just also wanted to say that I frequent this forum a lot b/c in my heart/head I do believe I am stage IV, and you ladies are an inspiration!  Thanks so much!      Lori, age 33, dx IBC Stage IV 8/09, Grade 3, ER+/PR-/Her2+, married with a 4 year old son and a 1 year old daughter Dx 8/21/2009, IBC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/25 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2010 01:49PM lorieg wrote: Hey ladies! I am 5 days out from my bilateral MRM.  My BS took 2 o the 4 drains out today.  That side feels much better!  Overall, I feel great.  I have been out and about and haven't spent anytime in bed (other than at night, lol) since I came home the morning after surgery.  I am off pain meds. Got my preliminary path report back....let me just say I started in August 09 with major involvement of the entire breast,  hnodes and a metastatic axillary node on the opposite side as my cancer.  I have IBC so it all popped up overnight, not like I ignored it or put of diagnosis/treatment.  3+ months of chemo did nothing to improve things.  Only in these last 3-4 months did the new chemo work.  Anyway, all 25 lymph nodes and all the skin were clear- NO cancer!  wohoo!!  Margins were clear but still had cancer in the breast which was expected.  My surgeon and I are thrilled.  Much better news than I ever dreamed looking at where I was in December.  Good luck to everyone this week!  You are all in my thoughts and prayers!

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 02:15PM lorieg wrote: Just a couple of helpful tips I thought I would pass along that the breast health nurse shared with me.... Once you are tired of the surgical bra (I wore one for 5 days to keep the swelling down, but it was really irritating my skin) try the night time nursing bras.  I breastfed my babies in the last few years so still have several.  Those of you who do not have any they can be bought at babiesrus or target.  They are nice and soft and comfortable. I do not have to keep my incisions covered but feel better with a dressing in place.  I have been using maxi pads to cover up the incision.  The stickiness on the back keeps it in place against the bra without any annoying tape needed, Good luck to all the ladies this week! Lori
